title: Cat. 54.4  L’univers est créé (The Universe Is Being Created), 1893/94
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Printed by Pola Gauguin (Danish, born France, 1883–1961), published by Christian Cato, Copenhagen  
L’univers est créé (The Universe Is Being Created), from the Noa Noa Suite  
1893/94, printed and published 1921  
Wood-block print in black ink on grayish-ivory China paper; 205 × 355 mm (image); 269 × 426 mm (sheet)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, the Joseph Brooks Fair Collection, 1924.1203  
Guérin 93, Kornfeld 18 II/II, E,b, Druick/Zegers 18  
For the verso, see fig. 54.4.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">In 1921 Pola Gauguin, the artist’s son, published a posthumous edition of ten Gauguin wood-block prints, printed in an edition of one hundred, among them eight from the Noa Noa Suite. The edition was printed in black on fine, grayish-ivory China paper. With a large proportion of absorbent filler used in the formation of the sheets, the paper was particularly conducive to absorbing the black printing ink from the block. Fillers in this type of paper were commonly clay- or chalk-based and had an affinity for the wet, tacky ink. In Pola’s impressions, the ink was wiped very cleanly from the blocks, with the result that even the most finely incised lines that Gauguin made transferred precisely to paper. This also provides the present-day viewer with a clear understanding of the manufacture of the blocks—constructed by adhering multiple smaller segments of wood together—since many of the small gaps that had developed in them over time appear as fine white vertical and horizontal lines scattered throughout the impressions. Similarly, the prints document the damage—small scratches and cracks—suffered by the blocks before 1921 as well as minute, delicate incising added by a later hand to clean up the blocks, perhaps in anticipation of the posthumous printing.

When placed side by side with the many unique impressions pulled by Gauguin, the impressions pulled by Pola lack tonal variation and differ greatly in appearance. Gauguin sought to obscure much of the gouged and incised detail carved into his blocks by unevenly and selectively inking them and by hand applying media to the block, the printed paper, or both. In contrast, Pola’s impressions have a crisp accuracy and legibility that allow them to be used as road maps to better navigate the imagery that was very consciously obscured in Gauguin’s impressions (fig. 54.4.2).

Several segments of the block used for this print (1893–94; Memorial Art Gallery of the University of Rochester, Rochester, New York), which was constructed from eight small pieces of end-grain boxwood, cracked or shifted out of plane at some point before the 1921 printing. These uninked areas resulted in visual breaks in the printed composition in the vertical direction 117 mm, 235 mm, and 323 mm in from the left edge, and in the horizontal direction 118 mm and 107 mm down from the top edge where the individual section of the block split. The block has suffered significant damage. A series of scratches are present in the lower left, a sharp diagonal scratch is present below the central fish, a large scratch extends between the two figures in the upper left, and hairline scratches are present through the monogram and in the upper right. The result of a significant flaw or damage in the block appears in the left side of the composition as uninked, ill-defined splotches that extend through the female figure. It is likely that the block warped or became misaligned, so that the inked roller did not come completely in contact with these areas.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 54.4.3).

RTI captures the work of art lit from multiple angles to enhance the surface topography of the wood-block print (fig. 54.4.4).

The posthumous impressions were printed with ink that is a mixture of carbon black and Prussian blue. The cool cast of the ink is attributable to blue pigment. The block was printed in a straightforward manner using a press. This undertaking was carried out in Copenhagen by the publisher Christian Cato; according to Pola Gauguin the blocks were printed using “a book press and two cylinders, one of moistened rubber and one of hard leather.” It is quite apparent that this impression was printed with a hard leather roller so the ink would remain on the surface of the block rather than slip into the interstices. The consistency of the ink must have been quite tacky to sit on the surface of the block in this way. Because only the highest points were inked, the rings of the wood absorbed the ink selectively; as a result, they are visible in the lower left part of the composition.

The paper fibers in the thin, grayish-ivory China paper are more or less uniform, with minute fibrous inclusions throughout. Calcium carbonate (chalk) was used as a filler to give the sheet its opaque, matte appearance and soft, velvety feel. There is a series of brush marks incised into the paper. A hallmark of China paper, these brush marks form when a hard-bristled brush is used to brush out the paper onto a hard surface to dry. Dragging the brush through the chalk-laden paper results in the pattern of brushwork seen here (fig. 54.4.5). In transmitted light, a mold impression characteristic of China paper is visible; chain lines appear at various intervals across the sheet and laid lines are very fine and spaced close together. The distribution of the varied paper fibers is also visible. Under magnification the paper fibers appear long and evenly distributed throughout the sheet. Some darker fibers of various lengths can be seen throughout. The ink is evenly dispersed on the surface. Creases that formed in the printing process are readily visible and the lack of ink in overlapping areas of creasing is apparent. Embossment of the paper is pronounced in raking light. Surface shape studies of a number of Gauguin’s wood-block prints, including this posthumous impression, were undertaken at the Art Institute using RTI methods adapted for use with photometric stereo to reveal textural characteristics that often defy recognition in normal light. Multiple images captured from a fixed-camera position, lit from multiple specific angles, are combined to create an interactive composite image to capture the topography of the paper, the manner in which the ink sits on the paper, and the appearance of the paper fibers (see fig. 54.4.4). The Pola impressions were not printed with the same degree of variable pressure as that applied by Gauguin. Therefore, they are not as deeply embossed as the lifetime impressions examined for this study. However, the paper in the image area exhibits pressure-induced undulations associated with the use of a press and the significant pressure exerted to print the block.

In 1938 Pola outlined his trials and tribulations as he worked out his method to print his father’s blocks. He stated that he purchased the blocks in 1919, and it must have been under the guidance of the Cato firm that he came to familiarize himself with the China paper favored by printers the world over by the late nineteenth century. Given the nuance and skill required to print such fine impressions, it is inconceivable to the authors that Pola printed the blocks alone without relying upon the expertise he found in Cato’s firm.

205 × 355 mm (image); 269 × 426 mm (sheet). The image was centered on the sheet with substantial borders of approximately 30 mm on each side. The sheet has hand-torn deckled edges along the left and top edges. The right and bottom edges were not cut down, and along both there are traces of red ink of the type customarily used to add export stamps to the outside of a large bundled stack of paper. It is likely that large sheets of China paper were cut in half or into quarters to provide sheets of dimensions appropriate for printing Gauguin’s elongated blocks. For this impression, the printer appears to have cut a large sheet of paper into quarters.

The publisher gave careful consideration to the manner of presentation of this group of wood-block prints. The images were centered on the large sheets of China paper with ample borders on all sides. The sheets of China paper were in turn pasted onto sturdy sheets of mottled blue wove paper in each corner (fig. 54.4.6). Blue fibrous inclusions appear throughout (fig. 54.4.7). Ample borders were again provided. The choice of this paper for mounting was not a random one, but one quite common in the latter part of the nineteenth century. It also reflected Gauguin’s own preference for mounting a number of his prints, including some from his Noa Noa Suite and multiple impressions of Oviri (see cat. 84.3 and cat. 84.4). Once mounted, the ten prints and a letterpress title page were placed in a portfolio constructed of gray millboard adorned with the cartouche from another plate in the suite, Te po (The Night) (cat. 52), on the cover (fig. 54.4.8).

Posthumous impressions in the Art Institute of Chicago are no longer mounted, the title page (fig. 54.4.9) was trimmed, and only the top of the portfolio cover (fig. 54.4.10) is extant; it, too, was trimmed.

The print is in very good condition overall. There are small losses in the upper left and upper right corners, and a larger loss that measures 8 mm along the right edge starting 53 mm down from the upper right corner. There is a pronounced vertical crease in the margin at bottom center and a smaller diagonal crease at bottom right that formed during printing. Neither extends into the image. On the verso there are various hinges adhered along the top (see fig. 54.4.1). There is slight golden yellow staining on the recto from these hinges. There is also a water stain in the upper right caused by the hinging adhesive. Examination under ultraviolet light reveals some foxing on both the recto and verso. The foxing predominates in the upper third of the sheet. The majority of foxing appears on the recto. These areas fluoresce less brightly than the rest of the paper. The paper is lighter where a mat protected it from light exposure. An area one-half-inch in width all around the image fluoresces darker than the rest of the sheet.  
Harriet K. Stratis with the assistance of Mary Broadway

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by Thomas W. Schreiner, New York, to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1924.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Art Center in La Jolla (Calif.), Post Impressionists, Aug. 7–Sept. 25, 1955, cat. 45.

Auckland (New Zealand) City Art Gallery, Paul Gauguin: Pages from the Pacific, Aug. 4–Oct. 15, 1995, cat. 18.

Art Institute of Chicago, Intimate Encounters: Paul Gauguin and the South Pacific; The Edward McCormick Blair Collection, Sept. 6, 2003–Jan. 11, 2004, not in cat.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Art Center in La Jolla (Calif.), Aug. 7–Sept. 25, 1955, Post Impressionists, exh. cat. (Art Center in La Jolla, 1955), n.pag., cat. 45.

Douglas Druick and Peter Zegers, Paul Gauguin: Pages from the Pacific, exh. cat. (Auckland City Art Gallery/Art Institute of Chicago, 1995), pp. 41, 52, cat. 18 (ill.).

Britt Salvesen, Gauguin, in association with Douglas W. Druick and Peter Kort Zegers, Artists in Focus (Art Institute of Chicago/Abrams, 2001), pp. 91, 109, no. 19b (ill.).

Art Institute of Chicago, Intimate Encounters: Paul Gauguin and the South Pacific; The Edward McCormick Blair Collection, exhibition brochure (Art Institute of Chicago, 2003), not in cat.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Signed lower right, below image, in pale silvery-purple graphite (copy pencil?): Pola Gauguin imp

Inscribed lower left, below image, in pale silvery-purple graphite (copy pencil?): Paul Gauguin fait

Inscribed upper left, above image, in pale silvery-purple graphite (copy pencil?): no. 50

Collection stamp in oval, lower left, in brown ink: THE ART / INSTITUTE OF / CHICAGO

Inscribed lower left, below image, in graphite: A. I. C. / 24.1203

Inscribed lower left, below image, in graphite, partially erased: acc. no. 6395

Inscribed lower left, in graphite: 6395

The media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (8–10×), and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm). The print was studied by means of photometric stereo.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Among the group of impressions of L’univers est créé (The Universe Is Being Created) examined in the Art Institute’s collection and elsewhere, a previously undocumented state between the first and second was discovered in the collection of the Princeton University Art Museum. This brings the total number of states to three.

Gauguin returned to Tahiti with the blocks for Te atua (The God) and Te faruru (Here We Make Love); for this reason they were not included in Pola’s edition.

It was previously suggested that block was composed of somewhere between six to ten sections. See Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine E. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 82. The block is in the collection of the Memorial Art Gallery of the University of Rochester, Rochester, New York.

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the artwork may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. Where annotations are available, the jagged-line icon brings up a list of them, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the artwork’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, ultraviolet, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the artwork as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular-arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom into or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

When the lightbulb icon is yellow, you can change the direction of light illuminating the work of art. To turn off this function, click on the lightbulb icon. To zoom in or out of the work of art, use the zoom function in the upper right of the image viewer (plus/minus signs). To move the work of art in the viewer window, turn off the lightbulb and click and drag the work of art in the direction you would like it to move. To see the work of art full screen, click on the full-screen icon. To return to the original view, click on the return icon (semicircle with arrow).

Pigment analysis of the ink was carried out using FTIR on Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (cat. 55.5) and Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) (cat. 60.4). Carbon black was identified as likely, and is mixed with Prussian blue. See Céline Daher, XRF analytical results summary, Dec. 2015, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago. Although these were the only posthumous prints analyzed, visual examination of multiple examples of posthumous impressions revealed that these works were all printed with the same type of ink. The tonality of the ink and its appearance on the paper are the same in all of them.

Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine E. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), pp. 48–49.

XRF analysis identified calcium carbonate (chalk) as the filler in Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (cat. 55.5) and Manau tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) (cat. 60.4). See Céline Daher, XRF analytical results summary, Dec. 2015, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago. Although these were the only posthumous print analyzed, visual examination of multiple examples of posthumous impressions revealed that these works were all printed on the same type of paper. The surface quality and tonality of the paper are the same in all of them.

The reflectance transformation imaging (RTI)/photometric stereo research project was undertaken at the Northwestern University/Art Institute of Chicago Center for Scientific Studies in the Arts (NU-ACCESS), generously funded through a grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. The work of Xiang Huang, who spent countless hours assembling the RTI images that appear in this publication, is especially acknowledged. See Oliver Cossairt, Xiang Huang, Nathan Matsuda, Harriet Stratis, Mary Broadway, Jack Tumblin, Greg Bearman, Eric Doehne, Aggelos Katsaggelos, and Marc Walton. “Surface shape studies of the art of Paul Gauguin,” 2015 Digital Heritage International Conference, ed. Gabriele Guidi, Juan Carlos Torres, Roberto Scopigno, and Holfer Graf, vol. 2 (IEEE, 2015), pp. 13–20, http://compphotolab.northwestern.edu/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Gauguin\_Final.pdf, doi: 10.1109/DigitalHeritage.2015.7419447.

I am grateful to Mel Becker Solomon for bringing Pola Gauguin’s 1938 essay in Galerie und Sammler (no. 6) to my attention. In the essay Pola expands upon what he had written in his 1935 letter to Jean-Gabriel Daragnès, published in Arts et métiers métiers graphiques 49 (Oct. 15, 1935), p. 40.

Correspondence dated April 2014 between Christine Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld) and Sten Rasmussen (buyer of NB Offset A/S and by descent the Cato Lithographic Establishment) states that he acquired a set of Pola impressions from the Cato archives along with the business. A document among Carl Schneiwind’s papers held in the Art Institute of Chicago, Department of Prints and Drawings, states that Pola lived next door to Cato and that “Cato probably made [the] Pola ed.”

Edgar Degas owned prints from the Noa Noa Suite that were mounted on mottled blue paper. See Ann Dumas, “Degas and His Collection,” in Dumas, Colta Ives, Susan Alyson Stein, and and Gary Tinterow, The Private Collection of Edgar Degas: A Summary Catalogue (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, 1997), p. 57.

An impression of Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) mounted on mottled blue paper is in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York; the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, owns mounted impressions of Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) and Te po (The Night).

In the Art Institute of Chicago collection there is a portfolio of fifteen lithographs after Degas by Georges William Thornley (1857–1935) published by Boussod, Valadon et Cie that is mounted in a similar fashion. The portfolio cover is intact. See also Commentary.

An intact example of the portfolio in the collection of the British Museum, London, was examined for this study. The observations made here are based on that examination.

I am grateful to Peter Zegers for so generously sharing his insights into Pola Gauguin’s posthumous edition of the Noa Noa Suite.

Harriet Stratis, condition report, 1995, conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 54.4 L’univers est créé (The Universe Is Being Created), from the Noa Noa Suite, 1893/94.

fig. 54.4.3 Gauguin’s L’univers est créé (The Universe Is Being Created) (1893/94, printed and published 1921). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.1203. Interactive image.

fig. 54.4.2 Details of three impressions of Gauguin’s L’univers est créé (The Creation of the Universe) (left and center, 1893/94; right, printed and published 1921). In the left and center images, taken from lifetime impressions, the artist’s desire to obscure details with selective inking and hand coloring are evident. By contrast, the posthumous Pola impression on the right renders all of the details in a crisp and clear manner. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.260, 1948.259, 1924.1203.

fig. 54.4.5 Raking-light detail of Gauguin’s L’univers est créé (The Creation of the Universe) (1893/94, printed and published 1921) showing bristle impressions left in the paper when it was brushed out to dry immediately after manufacture. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1924.1203.

fig. 54.4.4 RTI image of Gauguin’s L’univers est créé (The Creation of the Universe) (1893/94, printed and published 1921). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.1203. Interactive image.

fig. 54.4.6 The format of the posthumously published portfolio of Gauguin’s Noa Noa Suite, printed in 1921 by the artist’s son Pola Gauguin. The British Museum, London, 1925,0314.62.1–3. Photograph by Harriet K. Stratis.

fig. 54.4.7 The mottled blue wove paper used for mounting posthumous impressions of Gauguin’s Noa Noa Suite, printed and published in a portfolio in 1921 by the artist’s son Pola Gauguin. The British Museum, London. Photograph by Harriet K. Stratis.

fig. 54.4.8 The gray millboard portfolio cover containing Gauguin’s Noa Noa Suite, printed and published in 1921 by the artist’s son Pola Gauguin. The cartouche in the center is from another plate in the suite, Te po (The Night). The British Museum, London. Photograph by Harriet K. Stratis.

fig. 54.4.9 The title page included in the portfolio of posthumous Noa Noa Suite impressions, printed and published in 1921 by the artist’s son Pola Gauguin. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1924.1194a.

fig. 54.4.10 The portfolio cover in the Art Institute’s collection was trimmed to 319 × 450 mm. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1924.1194b.

fig. 54.4.1 Verso of Gauguin’s L’univers est créé (The Universe Is Being Created), from the Noa Noa Suite (1893/94, printed and published 1921). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.1203.

</section>
